subtopics.name: 1.1 Complete the Square
details: Use completed square form to locate the vertex of the graph or sketch the graph (ax²+bx+c).

subtopics.name: 1.2 Discriminant
details: Find and use the discriminant (ax²+bx+c) to determine the number of real roots; knowledge of 'repeated root' is included.

subtopics.name: 1.3 Solve EQ/INEQ
details: Solve quadratic equations and inequalities by factorising, completing the square, and using the formula.

subtopics.name: 1.4 Simultaneous Equations
details: Solve by substitution a pair of simultaneous equations (one linear, one quadratic).

subtopics.name: 1.5 Quadratic Form
details: Recognize and solve equations in x which are quadratic in some function of x (e.g., x⁴-5x²+4=0, tan²x=1+tan x).

subtopics.name: 2.1 Terminology/Concepts
details: Understand the terms function, domain, range, one-one function, inverse function, and composition of functions.

subtopics.name: 2.2 Range and Composition
details: Identify the range in simple cases; find composition gf (range of f must be within domain of g).

subtopics.name: 2.3 Inverse Function
details: Determine if a function is one-one, and find the inverse of a one-one function in simple cases.

subtopics.name: 2.4 Graphical Relation
details: Illustrate in graphical terms the relation between a one-one function and its inverse (include mirror line y=x).

subtopics.name: 2.5 Transformations
details: Understand and use transformations: y=f(x)+a, y=f(x+a), y=af(x), y=f(ax), and simple combinations.
Use terms 'translation', 'reflection', and 'stretch' in describing transformations.

subtopics.name: 3.1 Straight Line Equation
details: Find the equation of a straight line given sufficient information (e.g., two points, or one point and the gradient).

subtopics.name: 3.2 Line Forms and Use
details: Interpret and use y=mx+c, y–y₁=m(x–x₁), ax+by+c=0 for distances, gradients, midpoints, intersections, and parallel/perpendicular relationships.

subtopics.name: 3.3 Circles
details: Understand the equation (x–a)² + (y–b)² = r² (center (a, b), radius r).
Use the expanded form x²+y²+2gx+2fy+c=0.

subtopics.name: 3.4 Lines and Circles Problems
details: Use algebraic methods and elementary geometrical properties of circles (tangent ⊥ radius, angle in semicircle, symmetry). Implicit differentiation is not included.

subtopics.name: 3.5 Intersections
details: Use the relationship between points of intersection of graphs and solutions of equations (e.g., to determine the set of values of k for which a line intersects, touches, or does not meet a quadratic curve).

subtopics.name: 4.1 Radian Definition/Conversion
details: Understand the definition of a radian; use the relationship between radians and degrees.

subtopics.name: 4.2 Arc/Sector Area
details: Use formulae s = rθ and A = ½r²θ (θ in radians) in solving problems.
Includes calculation of lengths and angles in triangles and areas of triangles.

subtopics.name: 5.1 Graphs/Sketching
details: Sketch and use graphs of sine, cosine, and tangent functions (any size angle, degrees or radians).

subtopics.name: 5.2 Exact Values
details: Use the exact values of the sine, cosine and tangent of 30°, 45°, 60°, and related angles.

subtopics.name: 5.3 Inverse Notation
details: Use the notations sin⁻¹x, cos⁻¹x, tan⁻¹x to denote principal values of inverse relations.

subtopics.name: 5.4 Identities
details: Use the identities tanθ ≡ sinθ/cosθ and sin²θ + cos²θ ≡ 1 (e.g., in proving identities, simplifying expressions, and solving equations).

subtopics.name: 5.5 Solve Equations
details: Find all the solutions of simple trigonometrical equations lying in a specified interval. General forms of solution are not included.

subtopics.name: 6.1 Binomial Expansion (Positive Integer)
details: Use the expansion of (a + b)ⁿ, where n is a positive integer.
Includes notations $\binom{n}{r}$ and n!. Knowledge of the greatest term and properties of coefficients are not required.

subtopics.name: 6.2 AP and GP Recognition
details: Recognise arithmetic and geometric progressions.

subtopics.name: 6.3 AP and GP Formulae
details: Use the formulae for the nᵗʰ term and for the sum of the first n terms (e.g., $2b = a+c$ for AP; $b^2=ac$ for GP).

subtopics.name: 6.4 Geometric Convergence
details: Use the condition for convergence of a GP, and the formula for the sum to infinity.

subtopics.name: 7.1 Gradient/Notation
details: Understand gradient as limit of chord gradients (informal understanding).
Use notations f'(x), f''(x), dy/dx, and d²y/dx².

subtopics.name: 7.2 Standard/Chain Rule
details: Use the derivative of xⁿ (for any rational n), constant multiples, sums and differences, and composite functions using the chain rule.

subtopics.name: 7.3 Applications and Rates
details: Apply differentiation to gradients, tangents and normals, increasing/decreasing functions, and connected rates of change.

subtopics.name: 7.4 Stationary Points
details: Locate stationary points and determine their nature (using the second derivative or alternatives); use information in sketching graphs.
Knowledge of points of inflexion is not included.

subtopics.name: 8.1 Reverse Differentiation/Standard Forms
details: Understand integration as the reverse process of differentiation.
Integrate (ax+b)ⁿ (n ≠ –1), constant multiples, sums and differences.

subtopics.name: 8.2 Constant of Integration
details: Solve problems involving the evaluation of a constant of integration (e.g., finding curve equation given gradient and a point).

subtopics.name: 8.3 Definite Integrals
details: Evaluate definite integrals, including simple cases of 'improper' integrals.

subtopics.name: 8.4 Area/Volume
details: Use definite integration to find the area of a region bounded by curves and/or lines.
Use definite integration to find a volume of revolution about one of the axes.

subtopics.name: 1.1 Modulus Functions
details: Understand |x|; sketch y=|ax+b|; use relations like |a|=|b| ⇔ a²=b² and |x–a|<b ⇔ a–b < x < a+b when solving equations/inequalities.
Graphs of y=|f(x)| and y=f(|x|) for non-linear functions f are not included.

subtopics.name: 1.2 Polynomial Division
details: Divide a polynomial (degree ≤ 4) by a linear or quadratic polynomial; identify quotient and remainder.

subtopics.name: 1.3 Factor and Remainder Theorem
details: Use the factor theorem and the remainder theorem (including factors of the form ax+b).

subtopics.name: 2.1 Logarithms and Indices
details: Understand the relationship between logarithms and indices; use the laws of logarithms (excluding change of base).

subtopics.name: 2.2 eˣ and ln x Properties
details: Understand the definition and properties of eˣ and ln x, including their relationship as inverse functions and their graphs.

subtopics.name: 2.3 Solve EQ/INEQ
details: Use logarithms to solve equations and inequalities where the unknown appears in indices.

subtopics.name: 2.4 Linear Form Transformation
details: Use logarithms to transform a given relationship to linear form (e.g., y=k(aˣ) to $\ln y = \ln k + x \ln a$); determine unknown constants via gradient/intercept.

subtopics.name: 3.1 Reciprocal Functions
details: Understand the relationship of secant, cosecant, and cotangent to cosine, sine, and tangent.
Use properties and graphs of all six trigonometric functions for angles of any magnitude.

subtopics.name: 3.2 Identities
details: Use identities, specifically sec²θ ≡ 1 + tan²θ and cosec²θ ≡ 1 + cot²θ.
Use expansions of sin(A ± B), cos(A ± B), tan(A ± B).
Use double angle formulae for sin 2A, cos 2A, and tan 2A.

subtopics.name: 3.3 R-Formula
details: Express a sinθ + b cosθ in the forms R sin(θ ± α) and R cos(θ ± α).

subtopics.name: 4.1 Standard Derivatives
details: Use the derivatives of eˣ, ln x, sin x, cos x, tan x, together with constant multiples, sums, differences, and composites.

subtopics.name: 4.2 Product and Quotient Rule
details: Differentiate products and quotients.

subtopics.name: 4.3 Parametric/Implicit
details: Find and use the first derivative of a function defined parametrically or implicitly (e.g., in problems involving tangents and normals).

subtopics.name: 5.1 Standard Forms
details: Integrate e^(ax+b), 1/(ax+b), sin(ax+b), cos(ax+b) and sec²(ax+b).
Knowledge of the general method of integration by substitution is not required.

subtopics.name: 5.2 Trigonometric Integration
details: Use trigonometrical relationships (e.g., double-angle formulae to integrate sin²x or cos²(2x)).

subtopics.name: 5.3 Trapezium Rule
details: Understand and use the trapezium rule to estimate a definite integral.
Use sketch graphs to determine whether the trapezium rule gives an over-estimate or an under-estimate.

subtopics.name: 6.1 Locate Root
details: Locate approximately a root by graphical considerations and/or searching for a sign change (e.g., between consecutive integers).

subtopics.name: 6.2 Iteration
details: Understand the idea of, and use notation for, a sequence of approximations that converges to a root.
Use a given iterative formula of the form xₙ₊₁ = F(xₙ) to determine a root to a prescribed degree of accuracy.
An understanding that an iteration may fail to converge is expected.

subtopics.name: 1.1 Modulus Functions
details: Understand |x|; sketch y=|ax+b|; use relations for solving equations/inequalities.

subtopics.name: 1.2 Polynomial Division
details: Divide a polynomial (degree ≤ 4) by a linear or quadratic polynomial; identify quotient and remainder.

subtopics.name: 1.3 Factor and Remainder Theorem
details: Use theorems to find factors and remainders, solve polynomial equations, or evaluate unknown coefficients.

subtopics.name: 1.4 Partial Fractions
details: Recall and carry out decomposition where the denominator is no more complex than (ax+b)(cx+d)(ex+f), (ax+b)(cx+d)², or (ax+b)(cx²+d).
Excludes cases where the degree of the numerator exceeds that of the denominator.

subtopics.name: 1.5 Binomial Expansion (Rational n)
details: Use the expansion of (1 + x)ⁿ, where n is a rational number and |x| < 1.
Determining the set of values of x for which the expansion is valid is also included.

subtopics.name: 2.1 Logarithms/Indices/eˣ/ln x
details: Understand relationship and laws of logarithms (excluding change of base).
Understand properties of eˣ and ln x as inverse functions and their graphs.

subtopics.name: 2.2 Solve EQ/INEQ and Linear Form
details: Use logarithms to solve equations/inequalities where the unknown is in indices.
Use logarithms to transform a given relationship to linear form and determine constants.

subtopics.name: 3.1 Reciprocal Functions/Graphs
details: Understand and use secant, cosecant, and cotangent relations, properties, and graphs.

subtopics.name: 3.2 Identities and R-Formula
details: Use identities including sec²θ ≡ 1 + tan²θ and cosec²θ ≡ 1 + cot²θ.
Use expansions of sin(A ± B), cos(A ± B), tan(A ± B), and double angle formulae.
Express a sinθ + b cosθ in the forms R sin(θ ± α) and R cos(θ ± α).

subtopics.name: 4.1 Standard/Inverse Trig
details: Use derivatives of eˣ, ln x, sin x, cos x, tan x, tan⁻¹ x, together with composites.
Derivatives of sin⁻¹ x and cos⁻¹ x are not required.

subtopics.name: 4.2 Product and Quotient Rule
details: Differentiate products and quotients.

subtopics.name: 4.3 Parametric/Implicit
details: Find and use the first derivative of a function defined parametrically or implicitly (e.g., tangents and normals).

subtopics.name: 5.1 Standard Forms
details: Integrate e^(ax+b), 1/(ax+b), sin(ax+b), cos(ax+b), sec²(ax+b).
Include the integration of $\frac{1}{x^2+a^2}$.

subtopics.name: 5.2 Trigonometric Integration
details: Use trigonometrical relationships (e.g., double-angle formulae).

subtopics.name: 5.3 Partial Fractions Integration
details: Integrate rational functions by means of decomposition into partial fractions (restricted to types in 3.1).

subtopics.name: 5.4 f'(x)/f(x) Forms
details: Recognize an integrand of the form $\frac{kf'(x)}{f(x)}$ and integrate such functions (e.g., $\tan x$).

subtopics.name: 5.5 Integration by Parts
details: Recognize when an integrand can be regarded as a product; use integration by parts (e.g., x sin 2x, ln x, x tan⁻¹ x).

subtopics.name: 5.6 Substitution Method
details: Use a *given* substitution to simplify and evaluate definite or indefinite integrals.

subtopics.name: 6.1 Locate Root/Iteration
details: Locate approximately a root (sign change/graphical means).
Use notation for a converging sequence of approximations and use iterative formula xₙ₊₁ = F(xₙ).

subtopics.name: 7.1 Notation/Operations
details: Use standard notations ($\binom{x}{y}$, xi+yj+zk, **a**).
Carry out addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication; interpret these operations geometrically.

subtopics.name: 7.2 Magnitude/Unit Vectors
details: Calculate magnitude; use unit vectors, displacement vectors, and position vectors (in 2D or 3D).

subtopics.name: 7.3 Line Equation
details: Understand and use the form **r** = **a** + t**b**; find the equation of a line given sufficient information.

subtopics.name: 7.4 Lines Intersection/Skew
details: Determine whether two lines are parallel, intersect, or are skew, and find the point of intersection.

subtopics.name: 7.5 Scalar Product
details: Use formulae to calculate the scalar product; use in problems (e.g., angle between two lines, foot of the perpendicular). Vector product is not required.

subtopics.name: 8.1 Formulation
details: Formulate a simple statement involving a rate of change as a differential equation (includes constant of proportionality).

subtopics.name: 8.2 Separable Variables
details: Find a general solution for a first order DE where the variables are separable (using integration techniques from 3.5).

subtopics.name: 8.3 Particular Solution/Interpretation
details: Use an initial condition to find a particular solution.
Interpret the solution in the context of a problem being modelled.

subtopics.name: 9.1 Terminology and Equality
details: Recall terms: real part, imaginary part, modulus, argument, conjugate.
Use notations $\text{Re } z, \text{Im } z, |z|, \arg z, z^* $.
Two complex numbers are equal if and only if both real and imaginary parts are equal.

subtopics.name: 9.2 Cartesian Operations
details: Carry out addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of two complex numbers expressed in Cartesian form x + iy.

subtopics.name: 9.3 Conjugate Roots
details: Use the result that, for a polynomial equation with real coefficients, any non-real roots occur in conjugate pairs.

subtopics.name: 9.4 Polar Form and Argand Diagram
details: Represent complex numbers geometrically by means of an Argand diagram.
Carry out multiplication and division in polar form $r(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta)$.

subtopics.name: 9.5 Square Roots/Geometrical Effects
details: Find the two square roots of a complex number in exact Cartesian form (show working).
Understand the simple geometrical effects of conjugating, adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing complex numbers.

subtopics.name: 9.6 Loci and Inequalities
details: Illustrate simple equations and inequalities (e.g., $|z-a|<k, |z-a|=|z-b|, \arg(z-a)=\alpha$) by means of loci in an Argand diagram.

subtopics.name: 1.1 Identify Forces and Vectors
details: Identify the forces acting in a given situation (e.g., drawing a force diagram).
Understand the vector nature of force; find and use components and resultants (calculations required, not scale drawing).

subtopics.name: 1.2 Equilibrium
details: Use the principle that the vector sum of forces is zero, or equivalently, that the sum of the components in any direction is zero.

subtopics.name: 1.3 Friction and Contact Forces
details: Understand contact force has normal and frictional components; use the model of a 'smooth' contact.
Understand limiting friction and equilibrium; use the relationship F = μR or F ≤ μR.

subtopics.name: 1.4 Newton's Third Law
details: Use Newton’s third law (action and reaction are equal and opposite).

topics.name: 2. Kinematics of motion in a straight line

subtopics.name: 2.1 Scalar/Vector Concepts
details: Understand distance/speed (scalar) vs. displacement/velocity/acceleration (vector). Restricted to motion in one dimension only.

subtopics.name: 2.2 Graphs
details: Sketch and interpret displacement–time and velocity–time graphs (gradient/area relationships).

subtopics.name: 2.3 Calculus Use
details: Use differentiation and integration w.r.t. time to solve problems (calculus techniques restricted to P1 content).

subtopics.name: 2.4 Constant Acceleration Formulae
details: Use appropriate formulae for motion with constant acceleration (suvat equations).

subtopics.name: 3.1 Linear Momentum
details: Use the definition of linear momentum; understand its vector nature. For motion in one dimension only.

subtopics.name: 3.2 Conservation of Momentum
details: Use conservation of linear momentum to solve problems modelled as the direct impact of two bodies (including coalescence).
Knowledge of impulse and the coefficient of restitution is not required.

subtopics.name: 4.1 Linear Motion Application
details: Apply Newton’s laws to linear motion of a particle of constant mass moving under constant forces (including friction, tension, thrust).

subtopics.name: 4.2 Mass and Weight
details: Use the relationship W = mg. Use the approximate numerical value 10 m s⁻² for g.

subtopics.name: 4.3 Inclined Plane/Vertical Motion
details: Solve problems modelled as motion of a particle moving vertically or on an inclined plane with constant acceleration.

subtopics.name: 4.4 Connected Particles
details: Solve simple problems modelled as the motion of connected particles (e.g., string over smooth pulley, towing).

subtopics.name: 5.1 Work Done
details: Understand the concept; calculate work done by a constant force (W = Fd cosθ). Use of the scalar product is not required.

subtopics.name: 5.2 Energy Concepts
details: Understand and use gravitational potential energy (GPE) and kinetic energy (KE) formulae.

subtopics.name: 5.3 Conservation of Energy
details: Understand and use the relationship between change in energy and work done by external forces; use the principle of conservation of energy.

subtopics.name: 5.4 Power
details: Use the definition of power as the rate at which a force does work (Average Power = Work Done / Time taken).
Use the relationship between power, force, and velocity P = Fv.

subtopics.name: 1.1 Data Presentation
details: Select a suitable way of presenting raw statistical data; discuss advantages/disadvantages.
Draw and interpret stem-and-leaf diagrams, box-and-whisker plots, histograms, and cumulative frequency graphs (including back-to-back diagrams).

subtopics.name: 1.2 Measures of Central Tendency/Variation
details: Understand and use mean, median, mode, range, interquartile range, and standard deviation for comparing data sets.

subtopics.name: 1.3 Cumulative Frequency Use
details: Use a cumulative frequency graph to estimate medians, quartiles, percentiles, and proportions.

subtopics.name: 1.4 Mean and Standard Deviation
details: Calculate and use mean/SD (including grouped/coded data) either from data or from given totals $\Sigma x$ and $\Sigma x^2$.

subtopics.name: 2.1 Selections and Terminology
details: Understand the terms permutation and combination; solve simple problems involving selections.

subtopics.name: 2.2 Arrangements
details: Solve problems about arrangements of objects in a line, including repetition and restrictions.
Questions about objects arranged in a circle will not be included.

subtopics.name: 3.1 Evaluation
details: Evaluate probabilities in simple cases by means of enumeration of equiprobable elementary events, or by calculation using permutations or combinations.

subtopics.name: 3.2 Rules of Probability
details: Use addition and multiplication of probabilities, as appropriate, in simple cases.

subtopics.name: 3.3 Exclusive and Independent Events
details: Understand the meaning of exclusive and independent events; determine independence by comparing P(A $\cap$ B) and P(A)P(B).

subtopics.name: 3.4 Conditional Probability
details: Calculate and use conditional probabilities in simple cases (e.g., tree diagrams).

subtopics.name: 4.1 Probability Distribution/E(X)/Var(X)
details: Draw up a probability distribution table for a discrete RV X; calculate E(X) and Var(X).

subtopics.name: 4.2 Binomial and Geometric Distributions
details: Use formulae for probabilities (B(n, p) and Geo(p)); recognise suitable practical situations.
Use formulae for the expectation and variance of the Binomial distribution.
Use formula for the expectation of the Geometric distribution.

subtopics.name: 5.1 Model Use and Tables
details: Understand the use of a normal distribution to model a continuous random variable; use normal distribution tables.
Sketches of normal curves may be required.

subtopics.name: 5.2 Problem Solving
details: Solve problems concerning X ~ N($\mu$, $\sigma^2$); includes finding probabilities or finding relationships between parameters.
Full details of the working should be shown for calculations involving standardisation $Z = (X-\mu)/\sigma$.

subtopics.name: 5.3 Binomial Approximation
details: Recall conditions ($n$ large, $np>5$ and $nq>5$) for Normal approximation to Binomial.
Use this approximation with a continuity correction.

subtopics.name: 1.1 Calculation and Mean/Variance
details: Use formulae to calculate probabilities for the distribution Po(m).
Use the fact that if X ~ Po(m) then the mean and variance are each equal to m.

subtopics.name: 1.2 Modeling and Approximation
details: Understand relevance of Poisson distribution as a model for random events.
Use Poisson as approximation to Binomial ($n$ large, $p$ small: $n>50$ and $np<5$ approx.).
Use Normal distribution (with continuity correction) as approximation to Poisson ($m$ large: $m \ge 15$ approx.).

subtopics.name: 2.1 Expectation and Variance Rules
details: Use E(aX + b) = aE(X) + b and Var(aX + b) = a²Var(X).
Use E(aX + bY) and Var(aX + bY) for independent X and Y.

subtopics.name: 2.2 Distribution Properties
details: If X is Normal, aX + b is Normal.
If X and Y are independent Normal, aX + bY is Normal.
If X and Y are independent Poisson, X + Y is Poisson.

subtopics.name: 3.1 Probability Density Function (PDF)
details: Understand CRV concept; recall and use properties of a PDF (defined over a single interval).
Use PDF to solve problems involving probabilities, and to calculate the mean and variance.

subtopics.name: 3.2 Median and Percentiles
details: Locate the median or other percentiles by direct consideration of an area using the density function.
Explicit knowledge of the cumulative distribution function (CDF) is not included.

subtopics.name: 4.1 Sample and Population
details: Understand the distinction; appreciate the necessity for randomness in choosing samples.
Explain why a given sampling method may be unsatisfactory.

subtopics.name: 4.2 Sample Mean Distribution/CLT
details: Recognize sample mean ($\bar{X}$) as a random variable; use $E(\bar{X}) = \mu$ and $Var(\bar{X}) = \sigma^2/n$.
Use the Central Limit Theorem (CLT) where appropriate (informal understanding required).
Use the fact that $\bar{X}$ has a normal distribution if $X$ has a normal distribution.

subtopics.name: 4.3 Unbiased Estimates
details: Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance from a sample ($s^2$).
A simple understanding of 'unbiased' is required ('accurate result on average').

subtopics.name: 4.4 Confidence Intervals
details: Determine and interpret a confidence interval for a population mean ($\mu$) (known $\sigma^2$ or large sample).
Determine an approximate confidence interval for a population proportion (large sample).

subtopics.name: 5.1 Terminology and Nature
details: Understand the nature of a test, one/two-tailed tests, null/alternative hypothesis, significance level, rejection region, acceptance region, and test statistic.
Outcomes are expected to be interpreted in the contexts in which questions are set.

subtopics.name: 5.2 Test Binomial/Poisson
details: Formulate hypotheses; carry out tests for single observations (Binomial/Poisson) using direct evaluation or Normal approximation.

subtopics.name: 5.3 Test Population Mean
details: Formulate hypotheses; carry out tests concerning the population mean ($\mu$) (known $\sigma^2$ or large sample).

subtopics.name: 5.4 Type I/Type II Errors
details: Understand the terms Type I error and Type II error.
Calculate the probabilities of making Type I and Type II errors in specific situations.
